title-group.article-title: Identifying distinct clusters of ICU survivors by integrating demographic, pre-admission quality of life, and clinical data: a large prospective cohort study

sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: ICU patients differ in pre-ICU health status, comorbidities, and diagnosis, forming a heterogeneous population with diverse long-term outcomes. This study explored whether clustering ICU patients by demographic, pre-admission quality of life, and clinical data, rather than by diagnosis, could identify subgroups that are more informative for patient-centered outcomes post-ICU.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Data from the MONITOR-IC prospective cohort study were used. Demographic, pre-admission quality of life, and clinical data from 2361 adult ICU survivors of six hospitals were used to identify clusters, using the k-prototypes algorithm. Data from five additional hospitals (n = 866) were used for external validation. Self-reported physical, mental, and cognitive functioning, and quality of life one year post-ICU were described.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The four identified clusters differed significantly in long-term physical, mental, and cognitive functioning, and quality of life. Cluster-A (n = 204), characterized by a healthy pre-ICU status, high disease severity, low Glasgow Coma Scale, and long ICU stay, had a relatively high quality of life at one year, despite experiencing a mean decline from baseline. Cluster-B (n = 877), also a healthy group before admission but less severely ill at ICU admission, reported the best outcomes. Cluster-C (n = 632) included younger, mostly female patients with moderate impairments both pre- and one-year post-ICU. Cluster-D (n = 648), characterized by a low education level and poor baseline health, reported impaired outcomes one year post-ICU, although improved compared to their pre-admission status. External validation confirmed the generalizability of these results.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study identified and externally validated four distinct clusters of ICU patients by integrating both clinical and non-clinical data. These clusters, which differed in long-term physical, mental, and cognitive outcomes, challenge conventional disease-based classification, and support a multidimensional approach to define subgroups of ICU patients.

sec.title: Trial registration
sec.p: The MONITOR-IC study was registered at ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT03246334.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1007/s00134-025-08052-3.

custom-meta.meta-value: © Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature and European Society of Intensive Care Medicine 2025

tr.td: This large prospective cohort study integrated demographic, pre-admission quality of life, and clinical data from six hospitals and identified four distinct clusters of ICU patients. The identified clusters, which differed significantly in long-term physical, mental, and cognitive functioning, and quality of life, challenge conventional disease-based classification, and support the use of multidimensional data to define subgroups of ICU patients.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Although millions of patients are admitted to an intensive care unit (ICU) every year, the typical ICU patient does not exist. ICU patients differ not only in their admission diagnosis and clinical condition, but also in their pre-ICU physical, mental and cognitive health [1]. Consequently, long-term outcomes—including quality of life—are difficult to predict based on ICU characteristics alone [2–4]. This may explain why, even within traditional diagnostic subgroups, substantial variability in long-term outcomes persists [5, 6].

The rise of machine learning, and specifically cluster analysis, has provided new opportunities to classify patients based on multidimensional similarities rather than predefined diagnostic labels, while also minimizing physician biases [7, 8]. Recent studies have demonstrated the potential of cluster analysis to identify novel subgroups of ICU patients with differing mortality rates [9–16]. However, most of these studies relied on diagnosis-based patient data (e.g. sepsis, or COVID-19), limiting their ability to identify broader subgroups that include patients with different diagnoses [10, 13–16].

Importantly, only a few of these studies have described the long-term outcomes of these clusters [15, 16]. This is unfortunate, as long-term outcomes, such as quality of life, are important to patients and their families [17, 18]. Moreover, studies that have explored such patient-centered outcomes have found only minor differences in physical health and no differences in mental health between clusters [15, 16]. One possible explanation is that key determinants of long-term outcomes, such as pre-ICU functioning and socioeconomic status, were not included in these analyses [4, 19–21].

Therefore, in this exploratory study, we aimed to investigate whether integrating demographic, pre-admission quality of life, and clinical data could yield novel ICU patient clusters, possibly moving beyond traditional diagnosis groups. We further explored whether these subgroups differed in their long-term outcomes, hypothesizing that a multidimensional clustering approach—incorporating both clinical and non-clinical factors—could identify subgroups that are more informative for long-term patient-centered outcomes post-ICU.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: Data from an ongoing multicenter prospective cohort study, the MONITOR-IC (ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT03246334), were used [22]. The MONITOR-IC was set up in 2016 to study the long-term impact of critical illness, including physical, mental and cognitive problems, and quality of life. This study was approved by the research ethics committee of the Radboud University Medical Center, CMO region Arnhem-Nijmegen, the Netherlands (2016-2724) and is conducted in accordance with the declaration of Helsinki. Each participant, or their legal representative, provided written informed consent.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: Data of patients ≥ 16 years old admitted to the ICU of one of the eleven participating hospitals for ≥ 12 h between July 2016 and January 2023 were used. Patients admitted to the ICU after cardiac surgery were excluded as these patients form a unique sub-group of ICU patients, characterized by a short ICU length of stay and a good long-term quality of life [5, 6, 23]. Patients were also excluded if they did not speak Dutch language or had a life expectancy of ≤ 48 h.

The dataset was split based on geographical location into a training dataset (six hospitals, including three university hospitals and three regional hospitals) and validation dataset (five regional hospitals).

sec.title: Data collection and measurements
sec.p: Patients, or their proxies in case patients were not able to, completed a questionnaire during admission, recalling their health status before hospital admission. Furthermore, demographic variables were collected, including living situation, education level and ethnicity. In case of non-response, participants received two reminders. These data have been supplemented with data from the Dutch National Intensive Care registry (NICE), which provides data on admission type, length of stay, comorbidities, vital signs, and laboratory parameters [24].

Input variables for clustering analysis were selected based on availability, literature review, and clinical relevance, and discussed with a multidisciplinary team, including experts in critical care medicine, nursing, epidemiology, and long-term outcomes [2, 19, 25, 26]. Literature review was focused on a possible association with long-term patient-centered outcomes, as we aimed to identify subgroups that are informative for long-term patient-centered outcomes post-ICU. Moreover, as the goal was to identify novel subgroups, no diagnosis or diagnostic categories were included in the analysis. The following variables were selected (for definitions and instruments used, see electronic supplementary material 1):
Demographics: age, sex, ethnicity
Socioeconomic status: education, income type
Social: living situation
Pre-admission self-reported functioning and quality of life: frailty, fatigue, anxiety, depression, cognitive symptoms, physical health, mental health, health-related quality of life and perceived health
Neurological status: Glasgow Coma Scale in first 24 h of ICU admission
Comorbidities at admission: renal insufficiency, Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), diabetes, immunological insufficiency, malignancy
ICU length of stay
APACHE IV severity of illness score at admission

At one-year post-ICU admission, participants received a follow-up questionnaire to evaluate long-term outcomes which included quality of life, perceived health, and physical, mental, and cognitive functioning. Physical problems included frailty, fatigue, and physical complaints, mental symptoms included anxiety, depression and symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder, and cognitive problems included self-reported cognitive functioning. Instruments used and their corresponding range are reported in electronic supplementary material 1.

As the goal was to explore the long-term outcomes of the identified subgroups, patients who did not respond to the questionnaire one year post-ICU were excluded from analysis, including patients who had died within one year post-ICU.

sec.title: Clustering analysis
sec.p: Missing data were imputed using a random forest-based imputation method [27]. However, patients with > 20% of selected variables missing were excluded from analysis. Multicollinearity was assessed and continuous data were log-transformed, scaled and centered.

A variant of the k-means algorithm, called k-prototype, was used to calculate the similarity between patients, as this algorithm allows the assessment of mixed data (numerical and categorical data) [28, 29]. Based on this similarity, determined by the distance between patients, clusters are formed and updated until the clusters stabilize. The number of clusters was determined using silhouette width. K-prototype clustering was performed with the Huang distance, five random initializations and a maximum of 25 iterations. In the validation dataset, patients were assigned to a cluster based on the smallest cumulative distance to the previously identified clusters. To assess the impact of excluding non-survivors and non-responders, sensitivity analyses were performed.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Descriptive statistics were used to assess differences between the training dataset and the validation dataset using the chi-square test, independent-sample t-test, or Wilcoxon rank sum test when appropriate. Continuous data were presented as means with standard deviation (SD) or medians with first and third quartile expressed as interquartile range (IQR), depending on their distribution. Categorical data were presented as numbers and percentages.

Differences in outcomes between clusters were assessed using the Kruskal–Wallis rank sum test or one-way analysis of means, depending on the distribution. Based on the Bonferroni correction for multiple comparison, p-values < 0.004 were considered statistically significant.
Analyses were performed with R software (R foundation for Statistical Computing), version 4.4.1, using the following packages: missForestPredict, clustMixType, gtsummary and ggplot2.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p:
Between July 2016 and January 2023 24,015 patients were admitted to one of the participating ICUs, of whom 13,270 were eligible (Fig. 1). The main reasons for exclusion were cardiac surgery (n = 5590) and mortality during ICU admission or before informed consent (n = 2657). From 6935 patients (52.3% of eligible patients), informed consent was obtained, of whom 4612 (66.5%) returned the baseline questionnaire. One year post-ICU, 315 patients (6.8%) had died. In total, 3251 (75.7%) of the survivors returned the one-year follow-up questionnaire. Responders differed from non-responders: non-responders were more often female, non-Dutch, unemployed, lower educated, and reported more pre-ICU physical and mental problems and a lower quality of life (electronic supplementary material 2).Fig. 1
Flowchart

Due to missing data, 24 patients (0.7%) were excluded from analyses, resulting in a training dataset of 2361 patients and validation dataset of 866 patients. Patient characteristics of both datasets are shown in electronic supplementary material 3. Among others, patients in the training dataset were more often female, were on average younger, reported more symptoms of fatigue, anxiety and depression, had a lower APACHE IV severity score, and had a shorter ICU length of stay compared to patients in the validation set.

sec.title: Cluster analysis
sec.p: After assessing multicollinearity, all 23 variables were included in cluster analysis. Based on the silhouette width (electronic supplementary material 4), a four-cluster solution was considered the best fit for our data, as a two-cluster solution (which had a greater silhouette width) was deemed insufficient to describe the heterogeneity in the data, based on previous studies and patient characteristics (electronic supplementary material 3) [2, 5, 6]. Sensitivity of the clustering solution to the number of clusters (k) is also visualized in electronic supplementary material 4. Using the k-prototypes algorithm, the clusters A, B, C and D, accounting for 8.6% (n = 204), 37.1% (n = 877), 26.8% (n = 632) and 27.4% (n = 648) of patients, respectively, were identified.

Figure 2 visualizes the differences between clusters, showing standardized mean differences for all continuous variables included in the cluster analysis. More details regarding the characteristics of the identified clusters are shown in Fig. 3 and described in electronic supplementary material 5. The long-term outcomes differed significantly between the four clusters and are described in Table 1. The pre-admission and one-year post-ICU quality of life scores are visualized in Fig. 4.Fig. 2
Standardized mean differences of continuous clustering variables (including demographic, pre-admission quality of life, and clinical data) across clusters. Positive and negative values indicate that the variable is relatively high or low in this cluster compared to other clusters. Thus, cluster-A has a low Glasgow Coma Scale and high APACHE IV score compared to other clusters, whereas both clusters A and B have fewer pre-ICU impairments and higher pre-ICU quality of life than clusters C and D. Cluster-C includes younger patients with lower disease severity, while cluster-D stands out due to more pre-ICU impairments and lower pre-ICU quality of life compared to other clustersFig. 3
Characteristics of the four identified cluster across all clustering variables (including demographic, pre-admission quality of life, and clinical data), illustrated with boxplots for continuous variables and stacked bar charts for categorical variables. This figure illustrates the low prevalence of comorbidities in cluster-A, and higher prevalence of COPD and diabetes in cluster-D. It also highlights the differences in income source (e.g., more retired patients in clusters B and D; more unemployed patients in clusters C and D), differences in gender (e.g., predominantly female gender in cluster-C), and differences in admission diagnosis (e.g., more cardiac arrest and trauma in cluster-A). Differences in pre-ICU frailty, fatigue, and quality of life between the clusters are also visibleTable 1
One-year outcomes of the identified clusters

Quality of life scores of the four identified cluster before admission and one year post-ICU admission, illustrated with boxplots

sec.title: Cluster-A—healthy pre-ICU status, high disease severity
sec.p: Patients in cluster-A had few comorbidities (e.g., COPD 5.4%, diabetes 8.3%, malignancy 2.0%), a good pre-ICU quality of life (median EQ-5D-5L index score 0.92, IQR 0.84–1.00), a high disease severity (mean APACHE IV score 97, SD 28), and impaired neurological status (median Glasgow Coma Scale 3, IQR 3–5) at ICU admission. They were often admitted to the ICU due to cardiac arrest (38.7%) or (neuro)trauma (25.5%). This was also reflected in the admission type: 1.0% of patients in this cluster (n = 2) were admitted to the ICU for planned surgery. Furthermore, patients in this cluster had a relatively long ICU length of stay (median 4.8 days, IQR 2.8–10.2), and the majority were mechanically ventilated (98.0%) and received vasoactive medication (78.9%) in the first 24 h of ICU admission. Before ICU admission, 49.5% had a paid job and 30.4% was retired.

Although patients in cluster-A reported on average a decrease in quality of life one-year post-ICU compared to pre-admission (mean change in EQ-5D-5L index score -0.11, SD 0.27), their median EQ-5D-5L index score was 0.84 (IQR 0.66–0.91); the second highest of all clusters. Furthermore, they reported few long-term physical, mental, and cognitive problems post-ICU (e.g., median number of physical complaints 1, IQR 0–4), with only patients in cluster-B reporting better functional outcomes.

sec.title: Cluster-B—middle-aged with few pre-ICU impairments
sec.p: Patients in cluster-B had a good pre-ICU quality of life (median EQ-5D-5L index score 0.89, IQR 0.83–1.00), with few pre-ICU functional impairments (e.g., median Clinical Frailty Scale [CFS] of 2, IQR 1–2). Although their pre-admission health was comparable to patients in cluster-A, they had a lower disease severity (mean APACHE IV score 56, SD 19), and a higher age (mean 65 years, SD 12). The majority (58.4%) of patients in this cluster was retired, and 29.4% had a paid job before their ICU admission. In the first 24 h of ICU admission, about half of the patients in this cluster received mechanical ventilation and vasoactive medication (51.7 and 56.9%, respectively).

Patients in cluster-B had a median post-ICU EQ-5D-5L index score of 0.88 (IQR 0.79–1.00), the highest of all clusters. Moreover, at one year post-ICU patients in this cluster reported no significant physical, mental, and cognitive problems.

sec.title: Cluster-C—younger with moderate pre-ICU impairments
sec.p: Patients in cluster-C had a low disease severity (mean APACHE IV score 42, SD 15), moderate functional impairments pre-ICU (e.g., median CFS 3, IQR 2–3), and a median EQ-5D-5L index score of 0.75 (0.53–0.85). Moreover, it was the only cluster with mostly female patients (67.4%) and the cluster with the youngest patients (mean age of 51 years, SD 14). Over half of patients (56.8%) had a paid job before ICU admission, 25.0% were unemployed, 10.6% performed unpaid work, and only 7.6% of patients in this cluster were retired. This cluster had the highest proportion of patients admitted to the ICU after planned surgery (39.9%) and a relatively short ICU length of stay (median 1.3 days, IQR 0.9–2.9).

Patients in cluster-C reported an improvement in quality of life compared to pre-admission (mean change in EQ-5D-5L index score of 0.09, SD 0.30) and a median post-ICU EQ-5D-5L index score of 0.81 (IQR 0.70–0.89). Similarly to before their ICU admission, these patients experienced moderate physical, mental, and cognitive impairments. For instance, at one year post-ICU they reported a median CFS of 3 (IQR 2–5) and median anxiety and depression scores of 4, compared to a median of 5 before ICU admission.

sec.title: Cluster-D—poor health status pre-ICU, not employed
sec.p: Finally, patients in cluster-D had a high age (mean 66, SD 11), low pre-ICU quality of life (median EQ-5D-5L index score 0.48, IQR 0.15–0.72), moderate to severe functional impairments (e.g., median CFS 4, IQR 3–6), and the highest proportion of patients with a low education level (53.6%). Moreover, the majority (60.3%) of these patients were retired, and 26.0% were unemployed. This cluster also had the highest proportion of patients with comorbidities, such as COPD (21.6%), diabetes (17.1%) and immunological insufficiency (19.3%). Patients in this cluster were most frequently admitted to the ICU due to cardiovascular problems such as sepsis (29.8%) or pulmonary problems such as pneumonia (26.1%).

In this cluster the largest increase in quality of life was observed compared to pre-admission (mean change in EQ-5D-5L index score 0.22, SD 0.38). However, one year post-ICU their quality of life was still lowest of all clusters (median EQ-5D-5L index score 0.70, IQR 0.50–0.81). Moreover, patients in this cluster reported the most physical, mental, and cognitive problems one year post-ICU: the median CFS in this cluster was 3 (IQR 0–6), and median anxiety and depression scores were 6 (IQR 3–9).

sec.title: Generalizability and robustness of clusters
sec.p: In the validation dataset (n = 866), cluster-A accounted for 9.6% (n = 83), cluster-B for 40.2% (n = 348), cluster-C for 23.7% (n = 205), and cluster-D for 26.6% (n = 230) of patients. The characteristics of the clusters in the validation dataset were similar to those in the training dataset (electronic supplementary material 6). Also, the outcomes were very similar, with cluster-A reporting on average the largest decrease in quality of life (mean − 0.04, SD 0.19), and cluster-D reporting on average the largest increase in quality of life (mean 0.21, SD 0.39) (electronic supplementary material 7). Comparable to the training dataset, cluster-D had the lowest post-ICU quality of life (median EQ-5D-5L index score 0.73, IQR 0.58–0.83) and cluster-B had the highest with a median score of 0.89 (IQR 0.81–1.00).

To evaluate potential selection bias, clustering was repeated using data from all ICU survivors (n = 3379), regardless of one-year survival or questionnaire completion. The resulting clusters were similar to the original clusters, with some variation in clinical characteristics (electronic supplementary material 8): clusters B, C and D showed slightly greater impairments, while cluster A had fewer and was no longer characterized by high disease severity. Patients who were lost to follow-up were more often assigned to clusters C and D. This is in line with observed baseline differences between responders and non-responders (electronic supplementary material 2), as several characteristics of clusters C and D, such as poorer pre-ICU health, unemployment, and lower education, were more prevalent among non-responders.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this large prospective cohort study, four distinct clusters of ICU patients were identified using demographic, pre-admission quality of life, and clinical data. The identified clusters differed in their long-term physical, mental, and cognitive functioning, as well as overall quality of life. Cluster-A (healthy pre-ICU status, high disease severity), characterized by a low Glasgow Coma Scale score and high APACHE IV score at admission, reported the largest decrease in quality of life one year post-ICU. However, these patients still reported few functional impairments post-ICU, corresponding with their good health status before admission. Patients in cluster-B (middle-aged with few pre-ICU impairments), the largest patient group and a healthy group before admission, had a shorter ICU length of stay, lower disease severity and reported the highest quality of life scores post-ICU. Cluster-C (younger with moderate pre-ICU impairments) included mostly female patients and reported moderate impairments both before and one year after ICU admission. Cluster-D (poor health status pre-ICU, not employed) was characterized by a high age, low education level and the highest rates of comorbidities. Patients in this cluster reported impaired outcomes one year post-ICU, albeit improved compared to their pre-admission status. These results were confirmed by external validation.

Interestingly, the Glasgow Coma Scale was significantly lower in cluster-A, and this cluster-A also reported the largest decrease in quality of life one year post-ICU compared to pre-admission. This is in line with previous studies that have identified neurological status as an important determinant of long-term outcomes after critical illness [26]. Furthermore, patients admitted to the ICU due to cardiac arrest or neurotrauma—both also common admission reasons in cluster-A—have been found to often experience a decrease in quality of life post-ICU [6]. These findings stress the importance of considering neurological status when evaluating expected long-term outcomes.

While cluster-A (healthy pre-ICU status, high disease severity) shared similarities with traditional diagnosis groups, the other clusters were not characterized by specific admission diagnoses. This highlights a key strength of clustering with a multidimensional approach: the ability to identify novel patient subgroups that share other similarities. For instance, cluster-C was characterized by a relatively young and predominantly female population, with moderate impairments both before and after ICU admission. Rather than attributing these outcomes to gender or age alone, these findings should be interpreted in the context of social factors, such as unemployment, unpaid labor (see electronic supplementary material 6), and potential disparities in healthcare access. Although gender and age-sensitive approaches may help to tailor care, future research is needed to understand underlying mechanisms—such as coping, social support, and systemic disparities—that may inform more individualized interventions.

Moreover, the long-term outcomes of the identified clusters differed significantly. Previously, a median quality of life < 0.80 had only been described in small subgroups, such as patients admitted due to COPD or patients with chronic renal failure [5, 6]. In this study, however, cluster-D (poor health status pre-ICU, not employed) had a median post-ICU quality of life of 0.70, while representing 27.4% of the ICU population. Although their pre-ICU health status puts these outcomes into perspective, these patients may still benefit from additional post-ICU support.

These findings underline the importance of considering pre-admission health status, ranging from functional status to comorbidities, when evaluating long-term outcomes after critical illness. This builds upon previous studies, arguing that the long-term problems seen after critical illness are often related to patients’ comorbidities, pre-ICU functioning, and socioeconomic environment, rather than to critical illness itself [19, 25, 30]. For example, the long-term impairments in clusters C and D may be attributed to these patients’ pre-admission status, as they already reported moderate to severe impairments prior to admission. Consequently, despite having the lowest quality of life scores post-ICU, these patients reported an improvement compared to their pre-admission quality of life score. Although it is possible that these improvements are a result of ICU treatment, it is likely that coping mechanisms such as acceptance, adaptation and reprioritization contribute to patients’ perceived quality of life [31–34].

While such psychological phenomena are sometimes regarded as a source of bias, they are inherent to patient-reported outcomes [32]. These measures are designed to represent patients’ subjective experiences and perspectives on quality of life, which cannot be objectified, and provide unique insights into the experience and wellbeing of ICU survivors. Rather than a limitation, we consider the use of patient-reported outcome data as a core strength of our study, as these outcomes reflect what matters most to patients themselves [17, 35]. Previous qualitative and quantitative studies have shown that themes such as resilience, coping, individual values, and social support play a central role in how ICU survivors experience their quality of life post-ICU [33, 34, 36, 37]. Therefore, including validated psychological instruments in future studies could help us understand how personality traits contribute to variation in patient-reported outcomes.

Using multidimensional data, this study identified novel subgroups of ICU patients, moving beyond traditional diagnosis-based classification. Although this is the first study to describe the long-term outcomes of ICU survivors based on clustering, a previous study incorporated aspects of patients’ pre-ICU health status such as frailty, similarly concluding that no single variable (e.g., age) was as informative as the combination of multiple variables, further supporting the use of multidimensional data [12]. Defining subgroups of ICU patients based on multidimensional data could contribute to evaluating heterogeneity in treatment effects, improving outcome predictions, and ultimately lead to more informed treatment decisions [10, 13, 38]. The multidimensional and patient-centered perspective of the clusters identified in this study offers a conceptual framework for identifying patient groups with distinct recovery needs, and contributes to our understanding of ICU survivorship. Further research is needed to explore how multidimensional clusters can be integrated into routine care to support individualized (post-)ICU care, such as risk stratification, follow-up and rehabilitation. Translating such machine learning approaches to clinical practice will require further validation by multidisciplinary teams, overcoming known barriers to implementation (e.g. clinicians’ lack of literacy and familiarity with machine learning tools), and systematic collection of patient-centered data (e.g., pre-ICU functioning and quality of life) [39, 40]. As an initial step, educating clinicians about multidimensional patient groups and exploring whether cluster-informed interventions can improve patient outcomes may help bridge the gap between exploratory clustering and real-world application.

This study does have some limitations. First, as the aim was to describe the long-term outcomes of the identified clusters, only one-year survivors who responded to the one-year follow-up questionnaire were included in analyses. Consequently, these clusters cannot be used to assess the risk of other adverse outcomes such as mortality. Second, the exclusion of non-responders likely resulted in selection bias, as patients who did not respond to the one-year follow-up questionnaire were more often lower educated and had a poorer pre-ICU health status (electronic supplementary material 2). Sensitivity analyses showed that patients lost to follow-up or deceased were more frequently assigned to cluster-D, indicating underrepresentation of this group. However, the overall cluster structure remained largely consistent when including all ICU survivors (electronic supplementary material 8), suggesting the clustering solution is robust despite potential selection bias. Third, collecting baseline data prior to ICU admission was often not feasible due to the unexpected nature of ICU admissions. As a result, many baseline questionnaires were completed during hospitalization, possibly leading to recall bias. However, a previous study has shown that most patients can adequately recall their pre-ICU health status [41]. Fourth, some of the questionnaires were completed by proxies instead of patients themselves. Although previous studies have concluded that patient and proxy responses are generally comparable, individual discrepancies due to the subjective nature of the measures may occur, warranting cautious interpretation [42, 43]. Fifth, clinical data, such as comorbidities and neurological status, were collected by clinicians during ICU admission. While this could introduce variability, the risk of measurement bias is limited by standardized reporting guidelines and data quality checks and audits [24].

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This large prospective multicenter cohort study integrated demographic, pre-admission quality of life, and clinical data from eleven hospitals to identify and validate four distinct clusters of ICU patients, that differed in long-term outcomes. This supports the use of a multidimensional approach to define subgroups of ICU patients.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors thank the study participants and ICU staff of the participating hospitals (Rijnstate Hospital, Canisius Wilhelmina Hospital, Bernhoven Hospital, Amphia Hospital, Maas Hospital Pantein, Jeroen Bosch Hospital, Elkerliek Hospital, Maastricht University Medical Center, University Medical Center Utrecht, Zuyderland Medical Center, and Radboud university medical center) for their contribution to this study. In particular, we acknowledge Brigitte Westerhof, Stijn Corsten, Esther Ewalds, Crétien Jacobs, and Monika Kerckhoffs for their role as coordinating intensivists.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: LP, KS, MvdB, and MZ designed the study. KS, JvdH, MvdW, SvS, TR, MdV, MvdB and MZ contributed substantially to the acquisition of data. LP and LH performed the statistical analyses, with the support of KB and under the supervision of MY. LP, KS, MvdB, and MZ were involved in the selection of variables. LP drafted the manuscript. All other authors provided critical revisions of the article and approved the final version of the manuscript submitted for publication.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This work was funded by Radboud university medical center and Jeroen Bosch Hospital.

notes.title: Availability of data and materials
notes.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request. The data are not publicly available due to them containing information that could compromise research participant privacy.

notes.title: Conflicts of interest
notes.p: None of the authors have competing interests to declare.

notes.title: Consent to participate
notes.p: Informed consent was obtained from all individual participants included in this study.

notes.title: Institutional Review Board approval
notes.p: The MONITOR-IC study (ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT03246334) was approved on August 23rd, 2016, by the local ethics committee of the Radboud University Medical Center, CMO region Arnhem-Nijmegen, the Netherlands (2016-2724).
